thread.title: U.S. Charges GM with Wire Fraud, Concealing Facts on Ignition Switch
thread.title_full: U.S. Charges GM with Wire Fraud, Concealing Facts on Ignition Switch

title: U.S. Charges GM with Wire Fraud, Concealing Facts on Ignition Switch
text:
U.S. Charges GM with Wire Fraud, Concealing Facts on Ignition Switch Auto maker agrees to forfeit $900 million in profits By Biography Christopher M. Matthews Updated Sept. 17, 2015 4:35 p.m. ET 
General Motors Co. admitted to criminal wrongdoing and agreed to pay a lower-than-expected financial penalty in the mishandling of a defective ignition switch, closing one chapter on a safety crisis that dented the auto makerâ€™s finances and reputation. 
GM will pay $900 million to settle the U.S. Justice Department case, which charged GM with wire fraud and scheming to conceal a deadly safety defect from U.S. regulators, according... To Read the Full Story, Subscribe or Sign In Popular on WSJ
